title: Robert F. Kennedy
deleted: On April 4, 1968, Kennedy gave an improvised speech at [[Indianapolis|Indianapolis, Indiana]] after [[Martin Luther King Jr.|Martin Luther King Jr]]. was shot and killed.<ref>{{Citation|title=Robert F. Kennedy's speech on the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr.|date=2021-01-15|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Robert_F._Kennedy%27s_speech_on_the_assassination_of_Martin_Luther_King_Jr.&oldid=1000586858|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2021-02-01}}</ref> Despite the fears of riots and concerns for his safety, he went ahead with his plans with his plans to attend a rally at 17th and Broadway in the heart of Indianapolis's African-American ghetto. He addressed the crowd, without many of them knowing, that Martin Luther King Jr. was killed. In his speech, Kennedy offered remarks for peace and unity within the country.
